verses.text: Love righteousness, you rulers of the earth; think of the Lord with upright minds, and seek him with pure hearts.
verses.comment: This opening verse calls rulers to govern justly, emphasizing that true leadership requires moral integrity. The call to love righteousness and seek God with purity echoes throughout Scripture (see Psalm 24:3-4).

verses.text: For he is found by those who do not test him, and shows himself to those who do not distrust him.
verses.comment: Seeking God sincerely, without arrogance or skepticism, leads to true encounter (compare to Jeremiah 29:13; also reflected in Christ's teaching on seeking and finding in Matthew 7:7).

verses.text: For twisted thoughts separate from God, and power, when it is tested, rebukes the foolish.
verses.comment: Wicked, distorted thinking creates a barrier to God's presence. God’s divine wisdom exposes and corrects folly.

verses.text: Wisdom will not enter a deceitful soul, nor dwell in a body enslaved to sin.
verses.comment: Participation in wisdom requires openness and purity. The continual theme of cooperation with God’s grace can be seen here—holiness and wisdom are linked (see Romans 6:12 regarding mastery over sin).

verses.text: For the holy spirit of discipline flees from deceit, avoids foolish thoughts, and is driven away when injustice comes near.
verses.comment: The wording ‘holy spirit of discipline’ hints at the close connection between God's Spirit and the sanctifying process in the believer’s life (compare Ephesians 4:30).

verses.text: For wisdom is a caring spirit and will not acquit a blasphemer of his words; because God is a witness of his innermost thoughts, a true observer of his heart, and an attentive listener to his tongue.
verses.comment: God’s omniscience is clear—He knows our hearts and words (see also Matthew 12:36). This shows that true wisdom includes reverence for God and responsibility for our speech.

verses.text: Because the Spirit of the Lord fills the world, and that which holds all things together knows every word spoken.
verses.comment: ‘Spirit of the Lord fills the world’ prefigures aspects of the New Testament understanding of the Holy Spirit’s omnipresence. The phrase ‘holds all things together’ is echoed in Hebrews 1:3, which describes Christ’s sustaining power.

verses.text: Therefore, no one who speaks unjustly will go unpunished, nor will justice overlook them.
verses.comment: God’s justice is both present and final. The idea of inescapable divine judgment is foundational for Christian doctrine; see Romans 2:5.

verses.text: A godless plan will be investigated, because the sound of a person’s words reaches the Lord, and his justice weighs out what is said.
verses.comment: Every deed and word is held accountable by God. The ‘investigation’ of secret plans points to God’s complete knowledge and impartial justice (compare Galatians 6:7).

verses.text: For the ear of jealousy hears all things, and the noise of murmuring will not be hidden.
verses.comment: ‘Ear of jealousy’ is a Hebraism referring to God’s zealous care and attention. Even secret grumblings are exposed before Him.

verses.text: So beware of useless murmuring and restrain your tongue from evil, for even secret words will not go unpunished, and a lying mouth destroys the soul.
verses.comment: The New Testament often warns of the destructive power of the tongue (see James 3:6). Interior disposition and self-mastery are important aspects of authentic Christian holiness.

verses.text: Do not chase after death by the errors of your life, nor bring destruction by the works of your hands.
verses.comment: Death is presented as something one can pursue by persistent sin. This anticipates the New Testament warning: ‘the wages of sin is death’ (Romans 6:23).

verses.text: For God did not create death, and he does not rejoice in the destruction of the living.
verses.comment: God is the author of life, not of death. This theme finds fulfillment in Jesus’ mission to bring abundant life (John 10:10).

verses.text: For he created all things for existence, and the creatures of the world are wholesome. In them there is no poison of destruction, and the realm of the dead has no power over the earth.
verses.comment: God’s creation is inherently good (Genesis 1:31). The absence of destructive purpose in creation points forward to the hope of the new creation free of death and sorrow (Revelation 21:4).
This verse reveals the indestructible nature of righteousness, anticipating the Christian doctrine of immortality found in Christ (John 11:25).

verses.text: But the ungodly, by their words and deeds, invited death; thinking death their friend, they pined away and made a covenant with it, for they are worthy to belong to its party.
verses.comment: Here, turning from God is depicted as a willful alliance with death. The phrase ‘covenant with death’ is echoed in Hosea and later interpreted through Paul’s teaching on willingly embracing sin (Romans 1:32). The text supports the traditional understanding that rejecting God brings spiritual ruin.
